messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Japanese Tamahagane Links
messages.msgSnippet: Rick, It d be interesting if there is such a thing. I think we d need a faster, higher volume, less man-hour intensive translator than me to find out, though.
messages.messageBody:
Rick,
It'd be interesting if there is such a thing.

I think we'd need a faster, higher volume, less man-hour intensive translator than me to find out, though.

Jim



Jim and Folk -

I know nothing beyond what is contained in the post. My guess is
that the author is referring to more modern, industrial methods that
approximate the tartara but produce tamahagane or a reasonable
facsimile without utilizing expensive charcoal and which methods lend
themselves to faster, higher volume, less man-hour intensive
production. I think you should go into the listed Japanese sites and
translate for us! ;o)

NC


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Japanese Tamahagane Links
messages.msgSnippet: ... tatara without using charcoal made from woods. ... Jim and Folk - I know nothing beyond what is contained in the post.  My guess is that the author is
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Interesting... any idea what this refers to:
>
> "Yasugi works had developed same directly deoxidation method as
tatara without using charcoal made from woods."
> ?


Jim and Folk -

I know nothing beyond what is contained in the post. My guess is
that the author is referring to more modern, industrial methods that
approximate the tartara but produce tamahagane or a reasonable
facsimile without utilizing expensive charcoal and which methods lend
themselves to faster, higher volume, less man-hour intensive
production. I think you should go into the listed Japanese sites and
translate for us! ;o)

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Japanese Tamahagane Links
messages.msgSnippet: Interesting... any idea what this refers to: Yasugi works had developed same directly deoxidation method as tatara without using charcoal made from woods. ?
messages.messageBody:
Interesting... any idea what this refers to:

"Yasugi works had developed same directly deoxidation method as tatara without using charcoal made from woods."
?

Jim



Folk -

On a knifemaking site, I came across the following post, likely by a
Japanese national, re current sources for tamahagane.

http://www.dfoggknives.com/discus/messages/7/453.html?1052233766

Note the links at the bottom of the post. Okay, the Princess Monouke
link is a loser, but the others are better. I particularly enjoyed
the sushi link, where the chef discusses the types and the lineage of
the sushi knife, relating it to nihonto. Enjoy!

NC


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
